ai_content: With the rise of Covid-19 cases, people are getting more stressed than ever before, which is leading to a surge in substance and alcohol abuse. In a recent study, it was found that 70% of Americans are using some form of drug or alcohol to cope with the stress of the pandemic. This is a very worrying trend and could lead to a public health emergency if not addressed. If you or someone you know is struggling with substance abuse, there are a few suggestions that may help. Firstly, medication-assisted treatment for alcohol or opioid use disorders may be an option. Take medicine as prescribed and continue your therapy treatment or support appointments in person or through telehealth services when possible. However, it is important to note that medication-assisted treatment can have side effects such as hallucinations and paranoia. Therefore, it is best to consult a doctor before using any medication. In addition, if you are unable to attend therapy or support appointments, you can call the National Helpline for Substance Abuse. ai_content: A shocking report has emerged that exposes the dangerous work conditions that employees are being subjected to amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Investigations reveal that several workplaces are failing to maintain social distancing protocols, putting the lives of workers and customers at risk. According to sources, several industries such as restaurants, factories, and supermarkets have been identified as high-risk areas where the spread of the virus is rampant. Despite several warnings, workers are forced to work in close proximity to each other and customers, increasing the risk of infection. To address this, a committee of workers and management has been formed to identify these scenarios and recommend suitable interventions. The committee has recommended the use of appropriate combinations of controls following the hierarchy of controls to limit the spread of COVID-19. The first control measure recommended is engineering controls such as the installation of physical barriers between workers and customers. Additionally, the use of contactless payment methods and curbside pickup can also be employed to reduce contact between workers and customers. Administrative controls such as staggering work schedules and implementing shift rotations have also been suggested. This would reduce the number of workers present in the workplace at any given time, reducing the risk of transmission. Lastly, personal protective equipment (PPE) such as masks and gloves have been recommended for workers who are unable to maintain social distancing. Employers have a responsibility to provide adequate PPE to their workers and ensure that they are using them correctly. While protecting workers is of utmost importance, it is equally essential to note that control recommendations or interventions to reduce the risk of COVID-19 are necessary to protect customers as well. It is high time that employers take the necessary measures to protect their workers and customers during these unprecedented times. Failure to do so could result in an outbreak in the workplace, putting the lives of countless individuals at risk.

The US Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use (US MEC) and the Selected Practice Recommendations for Contraceptive Use (US SPR) have recommended that healthcare providers should limit the use of contraceptives during this time. However, this has raised concerns among many women's rights groups who argue that access to family planning services is essential, especially during a pandemic. The Quality Family Planning Services (QFP) has come out in support of these groups and has recommended that healthcare providers continue to offer these services while taking necessary precautions. In a recent statement, the QFP has said that healthcare providers should consider offering telehealth services to reduce the risk of exposure to the virus. Additionally, they have recommended that healthcare providers should use personal protective equipment (PPE) and take necessary precautions when providing in-person services. The QFP has also urged healthcare providers to educate their patients about the risks and benefits of using contraceptives during the pandemic. While the pandemic has created unprecedented challenges for healthcare providers, the QFP believes that access to family planning services should not be compromised. They have called on healthcare providers to remain vigilant in providing these services while taking necessary precautions to keep themselves and their patients safe.

ai_content: Saudi Arabia Assists in Airlifting WHO Medical Supplies to Yemen Saudi Arabia has aided in the airlifting of medical equipment and supplies from the World Health Organization's (WHO) logistics hub in Dubai to Aden, Yemen, on March 23.
